sen.j: 勝川 春章（かつかわ しゅんしょう、享保11年（1726年） - 寛政4年12月8日 (旧暦)（1793年1月19日））は、江戸時代の浮世絵師。
sen.e: Shunsho KATSUKAWA (1726 - January 19, 1783) was an ukiyoe artist who lived in the Edo period.
Shunsho KATSUKAWA (1726 - January 19, 1793) was an ukiyoe artist in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: ・「1793年」が「1783」となっていたので修正しました。・who livedが余分と思われるので削除しました。
sen.e: Shunsho KATSUKAWA (1726 - January 19, 1793) was an ukiyoe artist in the Edo period.

sen.j: 本姓は不詳、俗称は要助（あるいは祐助とも）。
sen.e: His real last name was never known, and his nick name was Yosuke (or Yusuke).
His real last name is unknown, but his nickname was Yosuke (or Yusuke).
sen.cmt: ・「不詳」は現在において不明ということだと思いますので、現在形にしました。・接続詞を変更しました。・nicknameを１語にしました。
sen.e: His real last name is unknown, but his nickname was Yosuke (or Yusuke).
He studied under Shunsui Miyagawa.
He studied under Shunsui Miyagawa.
He studied under Shunsui Miyagawa.

sen.j: 画姓は初め宮川、または勝宮川、後に勝川と称した。
sen.e: As his artist name, he selected the family name of Miyagawa, or Katsumiyagawa sometimes, and later called himself Katsukawa.
As an artist, he used the surname of Miyagawa or Katsumiyagawa at first, and later Katsukawa.
As an artist, he used the surname of Miyagawa or Katsumiyagawa at first, and later Katsukawa.

sen.j: 弟子には葛飾北斎がいる。
sen.e: One of his disciples was Hokusai KATSUSHIKA.
One of his pupils was Hokusai KATSUSHIKA.
One of his pupils was Hokusai KATSUSHIKA.

sen.j: 春章は、容貌を役者によって差別化しない鳥居派の役者絵とは異なる、写実的で、ブロマイド的な役者似顔絵を完成させ、大衆に支持された。
sen.e: Unlike kabuki actor paintings of the Torii School, Shunsho did not discriminate about how actors were drawn, established realistic portrait-like art, and was widely accepted by the public.

Shunsho established realistic art of kabuki actor portraits different from those by artists of the Torii school, who applied the same drawing style to every actor's portrait, and Shunsho's prints were widely accepted by the public.
sen.cmt: ・元の訳は、春章が「差別化しない」となってしまっているようですので、原文通り鳥居派が「差別化しない」となるよう変更しました。
sen.e: Shunsho established realistic art of kabuki actor portraits different from those by artists of the Torii school, who applied the same drawing style to every actor's portrait, and Shunsho's prints were widely accepted by the public.

sen.j: そのはじめとなったのは、一筆斎文調との合作として明和7年（1770年）に発表した『絵本舞台扇』である。
sen.e: His established style was first seen in "Ehonbutaiogi" that he published jointly with Buncho IPPITSUSAI in 1770.
His established style was first seen in "Ehonbutaiogi" (Books of Actor Portraits), which he published jointly with Buncho IPPITSUSAI in 1770.
sen.cmt: ・『絵本舞台扇』の説明を加えました。・関係代名詞をthatから非制限用法のwhichに変更しました。
sen.e: His established style was first seen in "Ehonbutaiogi" (Books of Actor Portraits), which he published jointly with Buncho IPPITSUSAI in 1770.

sen.j: その後、文調と比較して、明快な色彩と、素直で誇張のない表現で、人気を博した。
sen.e: Compared to Buncho's art, Shunsho's art was more vivid and honest with no exaggerations, and his work became popular.
Shunsho's works became popular, as they were vivid and honest with no exaggerations, compared to Buncho's.
sen.cmt: ・因果関係を明示する訳文にした方が自然と考え、変更しました。
sen.e: Shunsho's works became popular, as they were vivid and honest with no exaggerations, compared to Buncho's.

sen.j: 特に「東扇（あずまおおぎ）」の連作は、人気役者の似顔絵を扇に仕立てて身近に愛用するために、扇の形に線が入っており、大首絵（おおくびえ）の先駆的作品とされる。
sen.e: In his 'Azuma Ogi' series, a fan-shaped frame was drawn on each sheet of paper and the portrait of a popular actor was drawn in that frame so that it could be used as a fan, and this work style was believed to be the pioneer of an ukiyoe style called Okubie (or large-head pictures).

In his 'Azuma Ogi' series depicting portraits of popular actors, a fan-shaped frame was drawn on each sheet of paper so that people could use it to make a fan (ogi) and enjoy seeing it in their daily life, and this series' half-lengths are believed to have been the pioneering works later developed into Okubie ("large-head" pictures).
sen.cmt: ・「身近に愛用する」の部分を訳に入れました。・原文の「～とされる」が「～とされていた」となっていたのを修正しました。・pioneerが誤用と思われるので変更しました。
sen.e: In his 'Azuma Ogi' series depicting portraits of popular actors, a fan-shaped frame was drawn on each sheet of paper so that people could use it to make a fan (ogi) and enjoy seeing it in their daily life, and this series' half-lengths are believed to have been the pioneering works later developed into Okubie ("large-head" pictures).

sen.j: 勝川派は、役者似顔絵を得意として、多数の弟子を抱え隆盛する。
sen.e: The specialty of the Katsukawa School was actor portraits, and the school flourished with many disciples.
The specialty of the Katsukawa school was actor portraits, and the school flourished with many apprentices.
sen.cmt: ・Schoolのsを小文字にしました。・disciplesを変更しました。
sen.e: The specialty of the Katsukawa school was actor portraits, and the school flourished with many apprentices.

sen.j: 天明後期には勝川派を代表する座を弟子の春好と春英に譲り、春章は肉筆画に専念していく。
sen.e: At the end of the Tenmei era, he let his disciples Shunko and Shunei represent the school, and he started to focus on brush painting.
At the end of the Tenmei era, he handed over the leadership position of the school to his apprentices, Shunko and Shunei, and he started to focus on brush paintings.
sen.cmt: ・letが口語的なので変更しました。・disciplesを変更しました。・paintingを複数形にしました。
sen.e: At the end of the Tenmei era, he handed over the leadership position of the school to his apprentices, Shunko and Shunei, and he started to focus on brush paintings.

sen.j: 特に細密な美人画は当時から称賛されていたようで、「春章一幅価千金」と記されている。
sen.e: His bijinga (portrait of beautiful women) seem to have been highly recognized at that time and were described as 'Shunsho Ippuku Atai Senkin.'

His detailed bijinga (portraits of beautiful women) seem to have been highly recognized at that time, and were described as 'Shunsho Ippuku Atai Senkin' (One painting by Shunsho is worth a thousand gold coins).
sen.cmt: ・「細密な」を加えました。・portraitを複数形にしました。・「春章一幅価千金」の説明を追加しました。
sen.e: His detailed bijinga (portraits of beautiful women) seem to have been highly recognized at that time, and were described as 'Shunsho Ippuku Atai Senkin' (One painting by Shunsho is worth a thousand gold coins).

sen.j: 肉筆画の代表作としては、肉筆美人画「雪月花図」（三幅対、重要文化財指定、MOA美術館蔵）がある。
sen.e: One of the most famous brush paintings is a bijinga 'Setsugekkazu' (3-panel work, designated important cultural property, and owned by the MOA, Museum of Art).

One of his most famous brush paintings is a bijinga 'Setsugekkazu' (Paintings of Snow, the Moon, and flowers) (3-panel work, designated important cultural property, and owned by the MOA Museum of Art).
sen.cmt: ・theをhisに変更しました。・「雪月花図」の意味を訳出しました。・美術館の名称を公式サイトに従って、the MOA Museum of Art（コンマなし）としました。
sen.e: One of his most famous brush paintings is a bijinga 'Setsugekkazu' (Paintings of Snow, the Moon, and flowers) (3-panel work, designated important cultural property, and owned by the MOA Museum of Art).
